segment.source: Key-frame animations and easing function animations
segment.target: Key-frame animations and easing function animations

segment.source: Linear key-frame animations, key-frame animations with a KeySpline value, or easing functions are three different techniques for approximately the same scenario: creating a storyboarded animation that's a bit more complex, and that uses a nonlinear animation behavior from a starting state to an end state.
segment.target: Linear key-frame animations, key-frame animations with a KeySpline value, or easing functions are three different techniques for approximately the same scenario: creating a storyboarded animation that's a bit more complex, and that uses a nonlinear animation behavior from a starting state to an end state.

segment.source: Key-frame animations and easing function animations
segment.target: Key-frame animations and easing function animations

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Linear key-frame animations, key-frame animations with a KeySpline value, or easing functions are three different techniques for approximately the same scenario: creating a storyboarded animation that's a bit more complex, and that uses a nonlinear animation behavior from a starting state to an end state.
segment.target: Linear key-frame animations, key-frame animations with a KeySpline value, or easing functions are three different techniques for approximately the same scenario: creating a storyboarded animation that's a bit more complex, and that uses a nonlinear animation behavior from a starting state to an end state.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Make sure you've read the Storyboarded animations topic.
segment.target: Make sure you've read the Storyboarded animations topic.

segment.source: This topic builds on the animation concepts that were explained in Storyboarded animations and won't go over them again.
segment.target: This topic builds on the animation concepts that were explained in Storyboarded animations and won't go over them again.

segment.source: For example, Storyboarded animations describes how to target animations, storyboards as resources, the Timeline property values such as Duration, FillBehavior, and so on.
segment.target: For example, Storyboarded animations describes how to target animations, storyboards as resources, the Timeline property values such as Duration, FillBehavior, and so on.

segment.source: Animating using key-frame animations
segment.target: Animating using key-frame animations

segment.source: Key-frame animations permit more than one target value that is reached at a point along the animation timeline.
segment.target: Key-frame animations permit more than one target value that is reached at a point along the animation timeline.

segment.source: In other words each key frame can specify a different intermediate value, and the last key frame reached is the final animation value.
segment.target: In other words each key frame can specify a different intermediate value, and the last key frame reached is the final animation value.

segment.source: By specifying multiple values to animate, you can make more complex animations.
segment.target: By specifying multiple values to animate, you can make more complex animations.

segment.source: Key-frame animations also enable different interpolation logic, which are each implemented as a different KeyFrame subclass per animation type.
segment.target: Key-frame animations also enable different interpolation logic, which are each implemented as a different KeyFrame subclass per animation type.

segment.source: Specifically, each key-frame animation type has a Discrete, Linear, Spline and Easing variation of its KeyFrame class for specifying its key frames.
segment.target: Specifically, each key-frame animation type has a Discrete, Linear, Spline and Easing variation of its KeyFrame class for specifying its key frames.

segment.source: For example, to specify an animation that targets a Double and uses key frames, you could declare key frames with DiscreteDoubleKeyFrame, LinearDoubleKeyFrame, SplineDoubleKeyFrame, and EasingDoubleKeyFrame.
segment.target: For example, to specify an animation that targets a Double and uses key frames, you could declare key frames with DiscreteDoubleKeyFrame, LinearDoubleKeyFrame, SplineDoubleKeyFrame, and EasingDoubleKeyFrame.

segment.source: You can use any and all of these types within a single KeyFrames collection, to change the interpolation each time a new key frame is reached.
segment.target: You can use any and all of these types within a single KeyFrames collection, to change the interpolation each time a new key frame is reached.

segment.source: For interpolation behavior, each key frame controls the interpolation until its KeyTime time is reached.
segment.target: For interpolation behavior, each key frame controls the interpolation until its KeyTime time is reached.

segment.source: Its Value is reached at that time also.
segment.target: Its Value is reached at that time also.

segment.source: If there are more key frames beyond, the value then becomes the starting value for the next key frame in a sequence.
segment.target: If there are more key frames beyond, the value then becomes the starting value for the next key frame in a sequence.

segment.source: At the start of the animation, if no key frame with KeyTime of "0:0:0" exists, the starting value is whatever the non-animated value of the property is.
segment.target: At the start of the animation, if no key frame with KeyTime of "0:0:0" exists, the starting value is whatever the non-animated value of the property is.

segment.source: This is similar to how a FromToBy animation acts if there is no From.
segment.target: This is similar to how a FromToBy animation acts if there is no From.

segment.source: The duration of a key-frame animation is implicitly the duration equal to the highest KeyTime value set in any of its key frames.
segment.target: The duration of a key-frame animation is implicitly the duration equal to the highest KeyTime value set in any of its key frames.

segment.source: You can set an explicit Duration if you want, but be careful it's not shorter than a KeyTime in your own key frames or you'll cut off part of the animation.
segment.target: You can set an explicit Duration if you want, but be careful it's not shorter than a KeyTime in your own key frames or you'll cut off part of the animation.

segment.source: In addition to Duration, you can set all the Timeline based properties on a key-frame animation, like you can with a FromToBy animation, because the key-frame animation classes also derive from Timeline.
segment.target: In addition to Duration, you can set all the Timeline based properties on a key-frame animation, like you can with a FromToBy animation, because the key-frame animation classes also derive from Timeline.

segment.source: These are:
segment.target: These are:

segment.source: AutoReverse: once the last key frame is reached, the frames are repeated in reverse order from the end.
segment.target: AutoReverse: once the last key frame is reached, the frames are repeated in reverse order from the end.

segment.source: This doubles the apparent duration of the animation.
segment.target: This doubles the apparent duration of the animation.

segment.source: BeginTime: delays the start of the animation.
segment.target: BeginTime: delays the start of the animation.

segment.source: The timeline for the KeyTime values in the frames doesn't start counting until BeginTime is reached, so there's no risk of cutting off frames
segment.target: The timeline for the KeyTime values in the frames doesn't start counting until BeginTime is reached, so there's no risk of cutting off frames

segment.source: FillBehavior: controls what happens when the last key frame is reached.
segment.target: FillBehavior: controls what happens when the last key frame is reached.

segment.source: FillBehavior has no effect on any intermediate key frames.
segment.target: FillBehavior has no effect on any intermediate key frames.

segment.source: RepeatBehavior:
segment.target: RepeatBehavior:

segment.source: If set to Forever, then the key frames and their timeline repeat infinitely.
segment.target: If set to Forever, then the key frames and their timeline repeat infinitely.

segment.source: If set to an iteration count, the timeline repeats that many times.
segment.target: If set to an iteration count, the timeline repeats that many times.

segment.source: If set to a Duration, the timeline repeats until that time is reached.
segment.target: If set to a Duration, the timeline repeats until that time is reached.

segment.source: This might truncate the animation part way through the key frame sequence, if it's not an integer factor of the timeline's implicit duration.
segment.target: This might truncate the animation part way through the key frame sequence, if it's not an integer factor of the timeline's implicit duration.

segment.source: SpeedRatio (not commonly used)
segment.target: SpeedRatio (not commonly used)

segment.source: Linear key frames
segment.target: Linear key frames

segment.source: Linear key frames result in a simple linear interpolation of the value until the frame's KeyTime is reached.
segment.target: Linear key frames result in a simple linear interpolation of the value until the frame's KeyTime is reached.

segment.source: This interpolation behavior is the most similar to the simpler FromToBy animations described in the Storyboarded animations topic.
segment.target: This interpolation behavior is the most similar to the simpler FromToBy animations described in the Storyboarded animations topic.

segment.source: Here's how to use a key-frame animation to scale the render height of a rectangle, using linear key frames.
segment.target: Here's how to use a key-frame animation to scale the render height of a rectangle, using linear key frames.

segment.source: This example runs an animation where the height of the rectangle increases slightly and linearly for the first 4 seconds, then scales rapidly for the last second until the rectangle is double the starting height.
segment.target: This example runs an animation where the height of the rectangle increases slightly and linearly for the first 4 seconds, then scales rapidly for the last second until the rectangle is double the starting height.

segment.source: Discrete key frames
segment.target: Discrete key frames

segment.source: Discrete key frames don't use any interpolation at all.
segment.target: Discrete key frames don't use any interpolation at all.

segment.source: When a KeyTime is reached, the new Value is simply applied.
segment.target: When a KeyTime is reached, the new Value is simply applied.

segment.source: Depending on which UI property is being animated, this often produces an animation that appears to "jump".
segment.target: Depending on which UI property is being animated, this often produces an animation that appears to "jump".

segment.source: Be certain that this is the aesthetic behavior that you really want.
segment.target: Be certain that this is the aesthetic behavior that you really want.

segment.source: You can minimize the apparent jumps by increasing the number of key frames you declare, but if a smooth animation is your goal, you might be better off using linear or spline key frames instead.
segment.target: You can minimize the apparent jumps by increasing the number of key frames you declare, but if a smooth animation is your goal, you might be better off using linear or spline key frames instead.

segment.source: Note Discrete key frames are the only way to animate a value that isn't of type Double, Point, and Color, with a DiscreteObjectKeyFrame.
segment.target: Note Discrete key frames are the only way to animate a value that isn't of type Double, Point, and Color, with a DiscreteObjectKeyFrame.

segment.source: We'll discuss this in more detail later in this topic.
segment.target: We'll discuss this in more detail later in this topic.

segment.source: Spline key frames
segment.target: Spline key frames

segment.source: A spline key frame create a variable transition between values according to the value of the KeySpline property.
segment.target: A spline key frame create a variable transition between values according to the value of the KeySpline property.

segment.source: This property specifies the first and second control points of a Bezier curve, which describes the acceleration of the animation.
segment.target: This property specifies the first and second control points of a Bezier curve, which describes the acceleration of the animation.

segment.source: Basically a KeySpline defines a function over time relationship where the function-time graph is the shape of that Bezier curve.
segment.target: Basically a KeySpline defines a function over time relationship where the function-time graph is the shape of that Bezier curve.

segment.source: Typically you specify a KeySpline value in a XAML shorthand attribute string that has four Double values separated by spaces or commas.
segment.target: Typically you specify a KeySpline value in a XAML shorthand attribute string that has four Double values separated by spaces or commas.

segment.source: These values are "X,Y" pairs for two control points of the Bezier curve.
segment.target: These values are "X,Y" pairs for two control points of the Bezier curve.

segment.source: "X" is time and "Y" is the function modifier to the value.
segment.target: "X" is time and "Y" is the function modifier to the value.

segment.source: Each value should always be between 0 and 1 inclusive.
segment.target: Each value should always be between 0 and 1 inclusive.

segment.source: Without control point modification to a KeySpline, the straight line from 0,0 to 1,1 is the representation of a function over time for a linear interpolation.
segment.target: Without control point modification to a KeySpline, the straight line from 0,0 to 1,1 is the representation of a function over time for a linear interpolation.

segment.source: Your control points change the shape of that curve and thus the behavior of the function over time for the spline animation.
segment.target: Your control points change the shape of that curve and thus the behavior of the function over time for the spline animation.

segment.source: It's probably best to see this visually as a graph.
segment.target: It's probably best to see this visually as a graph.

segment.source: You can run the Silverlight key-spline visualizer sample in a browser to see how the control points modify the curve and how a sample animation runs when using it as a KeySpline value.
segment.target: You can run the Silverlight key-spline visualizer sample in a browser to see how the control points modify the curve and how a sample animation runs when using it as a KeySpline value.

segment.source: This next example shows three different key frames applied to an animation, with the last one being a key spline animation for a Double value (SplineDoubleKeyFrame).
segment.target: This next example shows three different key frames applied to an animation, with the last one being a key spline animation for a Double value (SplineDoubleKeyFrame).

segment.source: Note the string "0.6,0.0 0.9,0.00" applied for KeySpline.
segment.target: Note the string "0.6,0.0 0.9,0.00" applied for KeySpline.

segment.source: This produces a curve where the animation appears to run slowly at first but then rapidly reaches the value just before the KeyTime is reached.
segment.target: This produces a curve where the animation appears to run slowly at first but then rapidly reaches the value just before the KeyTime is reached.

segment.source: This is just one easing function example.
segment.target: This is just one easing function example.

segment.source: We'll cover more in the next section.
segment.target: We'll cover more in the next section.

segment.source: Easing functions
segment.target: Easing functions

segment.source: Easing functions allow you to apply custom mathematical formulas to your animations.
segment.target: Easing functions allow you to apply custom mathematical formulas to your animations.

segment.source: Mathematical operations are often useful to produce animations that simulate real-world physics in a 2-D coordinate system.
segment.target: Mathematical operations are often useful to produce animations that simulate real-world physics in a 2-D coordinate system.

segment.source: For example, you may want an object to realistically bounce or behave as though it were on a spring.
segment.target: For example, you may want an object to realistically bounce or behave as though it were on a spring.

segment.source: You could use key frame or even FromToBy animations to approximate these effects but it would take a significant amount of work and the animation would be less accurate than using a mathematical formula.
segment.target: You could use key frame or even FromToBy animations to approximate these effects but it would take a significant amount of work and the animation would be less accurate than using a mathematical formula.

segment.source: Easing functions can be applied to animations in three ways:
segment.target: Easing functions can be applied to animations in three ways:

segment.source: By using an easing keyframe in a keyframe animation, as described in the previous section.
segment.target: By using an easing keyframe in a keyframe animation, as described in the previous section.

segment.source: Use EasingColorKeyFrame.EasingFunction, EasingDoubleKeyFrame.EasingFunction, or EasingPointKeyFrame.EasingFunction.
segment.target: Use EasingColorKeyFrame.EasingFunction, EasingDoubleKeyFrame.EasingFunction, or EasingPointKeyFrame.EasingFunction.

segment.source: By setting the EasingFunction property on one of the FromToBy animation types.
segment.target: By setting the EasingFunction property on one of the FromToBy animation types.

segment.source: Use ColorAnimation.EasingFunction, DoubleAnimation.EasingFunction or PointAnimation.EasingFunction.
segment.target: Use ColorAnimation.EasingFunction, DoubleAnimation.EasingFunction or PointAnimation.EasingFunction.

segment.source: By setting GeneratedEasingFunction as part of a VisualTransition.
segment.target: By setting GeneratedEasingFunction as part of a VisualTransition.

segment.source: This is specific to defining visual states for controls; for more info, see GeneratedEasingFunction or Storyboards for visual states.
segment.target: This is specific to defining visual states for controls; for more info, see GeneratedEasingFunction or Storyboards for visual states.

segment.source: Here is a list of the easing functions:
segment.target: Here is a list of the easing functions:

segment.source: BackEase: Retracts the motion of an animation slightly before it begins to animate in the path indicated.
segment.target: BackEase: Retracts the motion of an animation slightly before it begins to animate in the path indicated.

segment.source: BounceEase: Creates a bouncing effect.
segment.target: BounceEase: Creates a bouncing effect.

segment.source: CircleEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using a circular function.
segment.target: CircleEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using a circular function.

segment.source: CubicEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t3.
segment.target: CubicEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t3.

segment.source: ElasticEase: Creates an animation that resembles a spring oscillating back and forth until it comes to rest.
segment.target: ElasticEase: Creates an animation that resembles a spring oscillating back and forth until it comes to rest.

segment.source: ExponentialEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using an exponential formula.
segment.target: ExponentialEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using an exponential formula.

segment.source: PowerEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = tp where p is equal to the Power property.
segment.target: PowerEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = tp where p is equal to the Power property.

segment.source: QuadraticEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t2.
segment.target: QuadraticEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t2.

segment.source: QuarticEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t4.
segment.target: QuarticEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t4.

segment.source: QuinticEase: Create an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t5.
segment.target: QuinticEase: Create an animation that accelerates or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t5.

segment.source: SineEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using a sine formula.
segment.target: SineEase: Creates an animation that accelerates or decelerates using a sine formula.

segment.source: Some of the easing functions have their own properties.
segment.target: Some of the easing functions have their own properties.

segment.source: For example, BounceEase has two properties Bounces and Bounciness that modify the function-over-time behavior of that particular BounceEase.
segment.target: For example, BounceEase has two properties Bounces and Bounciness that modify the function-over-time behavior of that particular BounceEase.

segment.source: Other easing functions such as CubicEase don't have properties other than the EasingMode property that all easing functions share, and always produce the same function-over-time behavior.
segment.target: Other easing functions such as CubicEase don't have properties other than the EasingMode property that all easing functions share, and always produce the same function-over-time behavior.

segment.source: Some of these easing functions have a bit of overlap, depending on how you set properties on the easing functions that have properties.
segment.target: Some of these easing functions have a bit of overlap, depending on how you set properties on the easing functions that have properties.

segment.source: For example, QuadraticEase is exactly the same as a PowerEase with Power equal to 2.
segment.target: For example, QuadraticEase is exactly the same as a PowerEase with Power equal to 2.

segment.source: And CircleEase is basically a default-value ExponentialEase.
segment.target: And CircleEase is basically a default-value ExponentialEase.

segment.source: The BackEase easing function is unique because it can change the value outside of the normal range as set by FromTo or values of key frames.
segment.target: The BackEase easing function is unique because it can change the value outside of the normal range as set by FromTo or values of key frames.

segment.source: It starts the animation by changing the value in the opposite direction as would be expected from a normal FromTo behavior, goes back to the From or starting value again, and then runs the animation as normal.
segment.target: It starts the animation by changing the value in the opposite direction as would be expected from a normal FromTo behavior, goes back to the From or starting value again, and then runs the animation as normal.

segment.source: In an earlier example, we showed how to declare an easing function for a key-frame animation.
segment.target: In an earlier example, we showed how to declare an easing function for a key-frame animation.

segment.source: This next sample applies an easing function to a FromToBy animation.
segment.target: This next sample applies an easing function to a FromToBy animation.

segment.source: When an easing function is applied to a FromToBy animation, it's changing the function- over-time characteristics of how the value interpolates between the From and To values over the Duration of the animation.
segment.target: When an easing function is applied to a FromToBy animation, it's changing the function- over-time characteristics of how the value interpolates between the From and To values over the Duration of the animation.

segment.source: Without an easing function, that would be a linear interpolation.
segment.target: Without an easing function, that would be a linear interpolation.

segment.source: Discrete object value animations
segment.target: Discrete object value animations

segment.source: One type of animation deserves special mention because it's the only way you can apply an animated value to properties that aren't of type Double, Point, or Color.
segment.target: One type of animation deserves special mention because it's the only way you can apply an animated value to properties that aren't of type Double, Point, or Color.

segment.source: This is the key-frame animation ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames.
segment.target: This is the key-frame animation ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames.

segment.source: Animating using Object values is different because there's no possibility of interpolating the values between the frames.
segment.target: Animating using Object values is different because there's no possibility of interpolating the values between the frames.

segment.source: When the frame's KeyTime is reached, the animated value is immediately set to the value specified in the key frame's Value.
segment.target: When the frame's KeyTime is reached, the animated value is immediately set to the value specified in the key frame's Value.

segment.source: Because there's no interpolation, there's only one key frame you use in the ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames key frames collection: DiscreteObjectKeyFrame.
segment.target: Because there's no interpolation, there's only one key frame you use in the ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames key frames collection: DiscreteObjectKeyFrame.

segment.source: The Value of a DiscreteObjectKeyFrame is often set using property element syntax, because the object value you are trying to set often is not expressible as a string to fill Value in attribute syntax.
segment.target: The Value of a DiscreteObjectKeyFrame is often set using property element syntax, because the object value you are trying to set often is not expressible as a string to fill Value in attribute syntax.

segment.source: You can still use attribute syntax if you use a reference such as StaticResource.
segment.target: You can still use attribute syntax if you use a reference such as StaticResource.

segment.source: One place you'll see an ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames used in the default templates is when a template property references a Brush resource.
segment.target: One place you'll see an ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames used in the default templates is when a template property references a Brush resource.

segment.source: These resources are SolidColorBrush objects, not just a Color value, and they use resources that are defined as system themes (ThemeDictionaries).
segment.target: These resources are SolidColorBrush objects, not just a Color value, and they use resources that are defined as system themes (ThemeDictionaries).

segment.source: They can be assigned directly to a Brush-type value such as TextBlock.Foreground and don't need to use indirect targeting.
segment.target: They can be assigned directly to a Brush-type value such as TextBlock.Foreground and don't need to use indirect targeting.

segment.source: But because a SolidColorBrush is not Double, Point, or Color, you have to use a ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames to use the resource.
segment.target: But because a SolidColorBrush is not Double, Point, or Color, you have to use a ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames to use the resource.

segment.source: You can use more than one DiscreteObjectKeyFrame for an ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames frame set.
segment.target: You can use more than one DiscreteObjectKeyFrame for an ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames frame set.

segment.source: This might be an interesting way to create a "slide show" animation by animating the value of Image.Source, as an example scenario for where multiple object values might be useful.
segment.target: This might be an interesting way to create a "slide show" animation by animating the value of Image.Source, as an example scenario for where multiple object values might be useful.
